Online_Linkage: https://alaska.usgs.gov/portal/project.php?project_id=82
Description:
Abstract:
This dataset contains migration timing and land-based location information from nine Marbled Godwits (Limosa fedoa beringiae) equipped with solar-powered satellite transmitters on breeding grounds near Ugashik, Alaska, in June of 2008. Transmitters were programmed with a duty cycle of 10 hr on and 48 hr off, yielding 10,858 locations (47-3,490 locations per bird, depending on the duration of each transmitter’s functional deployment). This dataset provides summarized timing and location data for each transmittered bird.
Purpose:
These data were collected in support of a study to document the poorly delineated basic aspects of migration ecology of the Alaskan subspecies of Marbled Godwits (beringiae). In particular, to describe individual migratory movements across years and to evaluate site use.
Supplemental_Information:
The source data with tracking locations obtained through the Argos System are available at: Ruthrauff, D.R., T.L. Tibbitts, R.E. Gill, Jr., and Douglas, D.C., 2019, Satellite Telemetry Data for Marbled Godwit (Limosa fedoa) (ver 1.0, 2019): U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/P9NORY48

Data_Quality_Information:
Attribute_Accuracy:
Attribute_Accuracy_Report:
Data are considered to be accurate and of adequate quality and resolution to answer the stated objectives. To conserve power, the satellite transmitters provided location data intermittently. Thus, the documented use areas and the estimated arrival/departure dates have margins of uncertainty. More details about the magnitudes of those uncertainties are described below in the Process Step section.
Logical_Consistency_Report:
The filtering algorithm that we applied to the source data (described in the Source Information section below) attempted to remove (filter) unrealistic values (e.g., physically implausible speeds or locations resulting in suspect turning angles) in a consistent, definable, and reproducible manner (details provided in the metadata of the source data; see Source Information section). Cause of variation in the number of locations and tracking duration for each animal is unknown, but generally related to factors such as mortality, transmitter detachment, or transmitter failure.
Completeness_Report:
Cells for which a value could not be calculated or determined are represented by "NA." Such instances occurred when a transmitter ceased transmitting and assessment of location or duration was not possible. This dataset represents only land-based locations (i.e., breeding, nonbreeding, and migratory staging sites). The data are complete and no values were omitted.
Lineage:
Methodology:
Methodology_Type: Field
Methodology_Description:
We used a helicopter staging out of the village of Ugashik to find nests and broods of godwits. We located godwits during overflights of likely godwit habitats. Upon observing a bird suspected of nesting or tending a brood, we landed the helicopter at a distance to observe the bird. If the godwit rejoined a nest, we gently placed a 6-m-long mist net over the nest and atop the incubating bird. When we observed birds exhibiting behaviors associated with brood attendance, we determined the approximate location of the brood, upon which we played a recording of chick distress calls to attract the adults. We then captured the adults by sweeping them out of the air in a 6-m-long mist net as they flew near the playback speaker. We fitted each adult with a 9.5 g solar-powered satellite transmitter (Microwave Telemetry, Columbia, Maryland, USA) attached over the bird’s synsacrum using a modified leg-loop harness constructed of 4.0-mm wide Teflon ribbon affixed with small brass crimps.

Type_of_Source_Media: digital database file
Source_Time_Period_of_Content:
Time_Period_Information:
Single_Date/Time:
Calendar_Date: 2019
Source_Currentness_Reference: publication date
Source_Citation_Abbreviation: ASC_Godwit_Telemetry
Source_Contribution:
This source provided processed satellite tracking data with implausible tracking locations excluded (filename: marbledGodwit_USGS_ASC_argos_diag_filteredLocations.csv).
Process_Step:
Process_Description:
We estimated the migratory timing and site use of Marbled Godwits throughout the annual cycle by visualizing the filtered location data (data available; see Source ASC_Godwit_Telemetry). We used Google Earth (Goggle LLC, Mountain View, California, USA) for visualizing the time-stamped tracking data for each individual godwit. We analyzed each godwits' locations in chronological order to document associated movements and site use. Because of the transmitters’ 10-hr-on/48-hr-off reporting cycle, we were often unable to determine the exact timing of a bird’s departure from or arrival to a site. In these instances, we estimated the timing of such movements by applying a series of decisions based on the timing of locations immediately prior to departures and following arrivals. In-flight tracks revealed that godwits did not travel over land other than when traversing the Alaska Peninsula while arriving at or departing from breeding sites. Thus, if transmitters detailed in-flight movements over marine waters within 100 km of either a departure or arrival site, we applied the rate of movement from those in-flight tracks to the first or last in-flight location to estimate the timing of departure or arrival, respectively. In the event that movements occurred such that we received no in-flight tracks, we assumed that the last on-land location prior to movement was the departure time, and applied a rate of 55 km hr-1 to estimate the time of arrival. For the purposes of this study, we defined a ‘site’ as any location visited by a godwit where at least 3 standard locations indicated local or no movement (i.e., rates of movement ≤55 km hr-1). Given the positional accuracy of the transmitters, we did not attempt to assess within-site movements and restricted our investigations to broad-scale movements. Further, we defined a nonbreeding site as the most southerly location that a particular godwit resided after their post-breeding migration, and a stopover site as any site visited outside of the breeding and nonbreeding periods during which a bird’s locations and rates indicated only local movement. In this way, we determined the timing of migratory movements, the sites associated with these movements, the duration of each stage of a migratory movement, and the overall duration of a migratory movement.
Process_Date: 2017
Spatial_Data_Organization_Information:
Indirect_Spatial_Reference:
Departure/Arrival site names are mostly derived from geographic names in the USGS Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) or the NGIA GeoNames System. They represent discrete areas along the Pacific coast used by Marbled Godwits in the study.
Direct_Spatial_Reference_Method: Point
Entity_and_Attribute_Information:
Detailed_Description:
Entity_Type:
Entity_Type_Label: marbledGodwit_telemetry_ugashik_ruthrauff.csv
Entity_Type_Definition:
Table showing the location and timing of migratory movements and stationary periods of nine Marbled Godwits marked with satellite transmitters near Ugashik, Alaska. Presented in a Comma Separated Value (CSV) formatted table.
Entity_Type_Definition_Source: Author defined
Attribute:
Attribute_Label: Sort_Order
Attribute_Definition:
A housekeeping column to ensure that each Marbled Godwit's migratory movements can be easily sorted to chronological order.

Attribute_Definition:
The last date and time that an individual was recorded at a site - Local Time Zone. Note that the migratory range of Marbled Godwits spans the Pacific and Alaska time zones, and so these dates and times reflect the local time zone and standard/daylight savings time.

Attribute:
Attribute_Label: Arrival_Site
Attribute_Definition:
Geographic location to which the Marbled Godwit arrived. Values represent generalized location names reflecting the most specific geographic name attribute feasible at the scale of each bird's movements.
Attribute_Definition_Source: Author defined

Attribute:
Attribute_Label: Stay_Duration_Hours
Attribute_Definition:
Duration of stay in hours at the arrival location associated with this record, calculated as the difference between the first record of the individual at the general location and the last record of the individual at the general location.
Attribute_Definition_Source: Author defined
Attribute_Domain_Values:
Range_Domain:
Range_Domain_Minimum: 1.63
Range_Domain_Maximum: 7190.23
Attribute_Units_of_Measure: Hours

The U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center is the authoritative source and distributor of these data.
Distribution_Liability:
Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes or on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
